repnme.cdata!: Sri Lanka - Health Sector Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Health Sector
            Development Project for Sri Lanka were as follows: outcomes
            were moderately satisfactory; the risk to development
            outcome was moderate; the Bank's performance was
            moderately satisfactory; and the Borrower's performance
            was also moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: decentralized health services work best when roles
            and responsibilities are clear, the central level fulfills
            its stewardship functions, and the decentralized levels are
            provided with adequate resources. In order to avoid
            disbursement delays, where there are many implementing
            agencies, special account reimbursements should not depend
            on consolidation of Interim Unaudited Financial Reports
            (IUFR) from all agencies. Piecemeal and fragmented
            implementation of civil works could have been avoided by
            development of a proper procurement master plan for works
            and a health infrastructure development master plan. While
            bed occupancy can provide a crude measure of efficiency for
            utilization of hospitals, it may be inappropriate for
            comparing hospitals of different capacities and levels.

repnme.cdata!:
Sri Lanka - Additional Financing of Health
            Sector Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Health Sector
            Development Project for Sri Lanka is to contribute to
            improvements in efficiency, utilization, equity of access
            to, and quality of public sector health services in Sri
            Lanka, with a particular focus on district and provincial
            level services. The additional credit will help finance the
            costs associated with originally planned project activities,
            facing a financing gap due to reallocation of USD 19 million
            of the original International Development Association (IDA)
            grant amount to Tsunami relief efforts and USD 3.5 million
            to avian influenza prevention. However, restructuring is at
            this time in terms of: (a) simplification of the component
            that supports the Central Ministry of Healthcare and
            Nutrition (MOHN), and allocation of proportionally more
            resources to the provincial/district level; (b) revision of
            the project development objective (PDO) making it more
            specific and realistic and of the results framework linking
            indicators more directly to the project activities; and (c)
            improvement of project management arrangements.
